Interpreting this material:

Of the 6,456 queues that ever existed during your crawl, 6,444 have been 
emptied/completed.

12 remain, and among them are 11,781,711 URIs. (It's always the big 
sites that are still being crawled at the end!)

At the moment of this report, all 12 queues were 'snoozed' -- pausing 
either to be polite to the target server, or to wait a reasonable amount 
of time to retry a connection-failure.

You would have to look at the logs and individual queues to know which 
is which. (A queue snoozing for a few seconds at a time and still 
leaving successes in the crawl log is just being polite; a queue 
snoozing for minutes at a time and only leaving connect-errors in the 
local-errors.log is hopelessly retrying an unresponsive web server.)

No evidence of a problem here, just the usual 'tailing off' of activity 
when only the large, slow, and dead hosts still have URIs left to crawl. 
The URIs left may also be trap/spam/junk/redundant material of 
negligible value, so based on your analysis of their value to you it may 
just be time to end the crawl.

- Gordon @ IA

> --- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Michael Magin <magin@...> wrote:
>> Take a look at your frontier report early in crawling and then later in 
>> the crawl.  I expect that you will probably find that late in the crawl 
>> there are relatively few active queues -- All the hosts which had 
>> relatively few URIs to crawl were exhausted earlier in the crawl -- now 
>> you're seeing the small number of hosts which have a large number of 
>> documents.
>>
>> (In some cases, this could be crawler traps, such as hosts which 
>> generate an infinite number of URLs, either through session ID 
>> parameters or other dynamically generated content, such as calendars.)
>>
>> Mike
>>
>> vretr wrote:
>>>
>>> hi,all.
>>>
>>> During the late period of crawling, the crawling data increases
>>> slowly, and the speed is usually lower than 5kb/sec, and few of
>>> ToeThread is in active state. What causes this problem? Is there
>>> something wrong with the software, hardware or crawling goals? How to
>>> solve the problems?
>>>
>>> thanks
>
